metadata.title: AMIRNET English Questions Database
metadata.description: Extracted English questions from Israeli Psychometric Exams

questions.question: The brown pelican, a seabird found in North and South America, catches fish below the ____ of the water.
Alexander Fleming discovered penicillin after ____ that a mold growing in his laboratory could kill bacteria.
The 1842 Webster-Ashburton Treaty ____ the dispute regarding the position of the Maine-New Brunswick border.
In some states in India, the consumption of alcoholic beverages ____.
Bushido, the samurai code of ____, demands self-discipline, respectful and ethical behavior, and absolute loyalty.
St. Patrick's Day, which ____ the patron saint of Ireland, is celebrated in many countries.
A period film is one that attempts to ____ depict a specific time in history.
At the end of the 19th century in the United States, huge crowds attended competitive walking races, the most popular ____ sport in the country.
For centuries, bars of salt – called amole – served as currency throughout Ethiopia.
options: Centuries ago, salt was a valuable commodity in Ethiopia.
Amole has been the currency of Ethiopia since ancient times.
Ethiopian salt was once prized all over the world.
Amole was an accepted means of payment in Ethiopia for centuries.
questions.correctAnswer: Amole was an accepted means of payment in Ethiopia for centuries.

questions.question: Despite never having collaborated, Isaac Newton and Gottfried Leibniz share the credit for pioneering the branch of mathematics known as calculus.
options: Newton and Leibniz were the first mathematicians to recognize calculus as a separate branch of mathematics.
The invention of calculus is attributed to both Newton and Leibniz, each of whom developed it independently.
Had they not shared their ideas about mathematics, neither Newton nor Leibniz would have discovered calculus.
To their credit, both Newton and Leibniz acknowledged each other's contribution to the field of calculus.
questions.correctAnswer: The invention of calculus is attributed to both Newton and Leibniz, each of whom developed it independently.

questions.question: Horticulturists at England's East Malling Institute are utilizing conventional breeding techniques rather than genetic engineering to produce giant strawberries.
options: By using genetic engineering instead of conventional breeding techniques, horticulturists at England's East Malling Institute could grow larger strawberries.
At the East Malling Institute in England, horticulturists are growing very large strawberries using conventional breeding methods, not genetic engineering.
According to horticulturists at England's East Malling Institute, giant strawberries can be produced using either conventional breeding techniques or genetic engineering.
Horticulturists at England's East Malling Institute have found that they can produce giant strawberries by using both genetic engineering and conventional breeding techniques.
questions.correctAnswer: At the East Malling Institute in England, horticulturists are growing very large strawberries using conventional breeding methods, not genetic engineering.

questions.question: The roots of opera can be traced to the Camerata, a group of Italian composers enamored of antiquity, who in the 16th century wrote music that emulated the tragic chorus in ancient Greek drama.
options: The Camerata, whose members were fascinated by the ancient world and whose works were modeled on the tragic Greek chorus, are considered the founders of opera.
The tragic Greek chorus, which was the inspiration for opera, was incorporated into the works of the Camerata, a group of Italian composers.
The operas composed by the Camerata in the 16th century were the first to abandon the rigid structure of the Greek chorus.
The enduring appeal of the operas written by the Camerata is a testimony to the impact of the ancient Greek chorus.
questions.correctAnswer: The Camerata, whose members were fascinated by the ancient world and whose works were modeled on the tragic Greek chorus, are considered the founders of opera.

questions.passage: Text I - Shakespeare's influence on English language
questions.question: An appropriate title for the text would be -
options: From Shakespeare to Facebook: The History of the English Language
The Plays of William Shakespeare: Language Perfected
Evidence of Greatness: Shakespeare's Language Reinterpreted
Lessons from Shakespeare: Helping the English Language to Evolve
questions.correctAnswer: Lessons from Shakespeare: Helping the English Language to Evolve

questions.passage: Text I - Shakespeare's influence on English language
questions.question: Which of the following strategies for creating new words is not mentioned in the second paragraph?
options: creating English versions of words from other languages
connecting two words that already exist

questions.passage: Text I - Shakespeare's influence on English language
questions.question: It can be inferred from the second paragraph that Shakespeare used suffixes -
options: to alter the meaning of existing words
more extensively than other methods of inventing new words
questions.correctAnswer: to alter the meaning of existing words

questions.passage: Text I - Shakespeare's influence on English language
questions.question: The main purpose of the last paragraph is to -
options: present David Crystal's criticism of the Oxford English Dictionary
show that today's English speakers continue to follow Shakespeare's example
questions.correctAnswer: show that today's English speakers continue to follow Shakespeare's example

questions.passage: Text I - Shakespeare's influence on English language
questions.question: It can be inferred from the last paragraph that David Crystal -
options: is one of the editors of the Oxford English Dictionary
believes that breaking the rules of language is irresponsible
thinks Shakespeare invented too many words

questions.passage: Text II - Pain and pain relievers
questions.question: An appropriate title for this text would be -
options: Feeling Pain and Dealing With It
questions.correctAnswer: Feeling Pain and Dealing With It

questions.passage: Text II - Pain and pain relievers
questions.question: The main purpose of the first paragraph is to -
options: explain what causes the sensation of pain
describe the role of prostaglandins in the body
explain how the brain responds to pain
questions.correctAnswer: explain what causes the sensation of pain

questions.passage: Text II - Pain and pain relievers
questions.question: According to the second paragraph, pain relievers -
options: should not be taken too often
are more effective against disease than injury
send healing signals to the brain
do not remove the source of the pain
questions.correctAnswer: do not remove the source of the pain

questions.passage: Text II - Pain and pain relievers
questions.question: "They" (line 15) refers, among other things, to -

questions.passage: Text II - Pain and pain relievers
questions.question: It can be inferred from the text that ibuprofen -
options: remains in the body long after it is taken
should not be used together with morphine

questions.question: There has been a decline in the population of honey bees ____.
Byron Nicholai is a popular Alaskan singer whose songs feature a ____ of words from English and his native Yup'ik.
The Gifu region in central Japan was ____ by the Great Earthquake of 1891.
Once common across Europe and Asia, the Eurasian beaver was nearly ____ by hunting in the nineteenth century.
The leaves of the dragon's blood tree collect ____ from the air, enabling the tree to survive in places where there is little water.
In November 2014, construction workers digging up a road in Iceland's Thingvellir National Park ____ paving stones from a road built in 1907.
Reviews of the 1995 film adaptation of Nathaniel Hawthorne's classic novel The Scarlet Letter were unfavorable, describing it as ____ at best.
In September 2012, the German government ____ media reports that it planned to stop using the Euro as the national currency, claiming they were absurd.
Every year, a hundred million monarch butterflies from across eastern North America converge on Mexico's Monarch Butterfly Biosphere Reserve, where they spend the winter.
options: A hundred million monarch butterflies come from all over eastern North America to Mexico's Monarch Butterfly Biosphere Reserve each year for the winter.
Mexico's Monarch Butterfly Biosphere Reserve was created as a winter habitat for the hundred million monarch butterflies of eastern North America.
During the winter, Mexico's Monarch Butterfly Biosphere Reserve is home to a hundred million monarch butterflies, most of them from eastern North America.
Each year, a hundred million monarch butterflies arrive at Mexico's Monarch Butterfly Biosphere Reserve after spending the winter in eastern North America.
questions.correctAnswer: A hundred million monarch butterflies come from all over eastern North America to Mexico's Monarch Butterfly Biosphere Reserve each year for the winter.

questions.question: Brain cells that have died from old age, injury or disease cannot be regenerated – or so it was long assumed, until research began to indicate otherwise.
options: For many years, people thought that once brain cells died, they did not grow back; however, studies have begun to show that this is not the case.
Studies now suggest that old age, injury and disease cause brain cells to deteriorate much more quickly than was previously believed.
Recent research supports what has long been believed – brain cells that have died cannot be regenerated.
Until research began to indicate otherwise, it was commonly assumed that brain cells damaged by old age, injury or disease could be repaired.
questions.correctAnswer: For many years, people thought that once brain cells died, they did not grow back; however, studies have begun to show that this is not the case.

questions.question: Given that the information regarding the final days of American author Edgar Allan Poe is fragmentary and contradictory, it is hard to imagine that there will ever be a completely satisfactory answer as to what caused his death.
options: The way in which Poe died will probably never be fully explained because the facts available are incomplete and inconsistent.
Recently discovered details about Poe's last days are being pieced together into a credible and persuasive theory about his death.
There is little consensus about the circumstances surrounding Poe's death.
The cause of Poe's death will remain a mystery until more is known about his final days.
questions.correctAnswer: The way in which Poe died will probably never be fully explained because the facts available are incomplete and inconsistent.

questions.question: Delivered in the waning months of the US Civil War, President Abraham Lincoln's second inaugural speech was notable for its brevity and its dispirited tone.
options: In the midst of the US Civil War, Lincoln gave his second inaugural speech, which was inspiring but restrained.
Towards the end of the US Civil War, Lincoln delivered his second inaugural speech, which was strikingly short and somber.
In his second inaugural speech, Lincoln displayed the same courage and vision that had proven vital during the US Civil War.
Lincoln's second inaugural speech, delivered shortly after the US Civil War, is remembered for its simplicity and its hopeful message.
questions.correctAnswer: Towards the end of the US Civil War, Lincoln delivered his second inaugural speech, which was strikingly short and somber.

questions.passage: Text I - Habits and the habit loop
questions.question: The main purpose of the text is to -
options: compare the characteristics of beneficial and harmful habits
explain the brain's role in establishing cues, routines and rewards
present an example of a habit loop that is difficult to change
discuss how habits are formed and how to change them
questions.correctAnswer: discuss how habits are formed and how to change them

questions.passage: Text I - Habits and the habit loop
questions.question: The main purpose of the second paragraph is to -
options: explain why teeth brushing is a beneficial habit
give an example of a habit loop
discuss the differences between cues, routines and rewards
present Charles Duhigg's book The Power of Habit
questions.correctAnswer: give an example of a habit loop

questions.passage: Text I - Habits and the habit loop
questions.question: In line 17, "an old one" could best be replaced by -

questions.passage: Text I - Habits and the habit loop
questions.question: Which of the following is an example of a habit loop?
options: paying your rent → buying a new sofa → saving money
waking up in the morning → eating a healthy breakfast → going to bed early
coming home from work → watching your favorite TV show → taking the dog for a walk
seeing your phone battery is low → charging the phone battery → being able to use your phone
questions.correctAnswer: coming home from work → watching your favorite TV show → taking the dog for a walk

questions.passage: Text I - Habits and the habit loop
questions.question: According to the text, a habit is -
options: a routine that cannot be changed
a craving with a one-time reward

questions.passage: Text II - Fibonacci and the Hindu-Arabic number system
questions.question: According to the text, the Hindu-Arabic number system -
options: is related to the Roman number system

questions.passage: Text II - Fibonacci and the Hindu-Arabic number system
questions.question: According to the second paragraph, Fibonacci -
options: dreamed of becoming a mathematician as a young boy
learned of the Hindu-Arabic numeral system in North Africa
was the first European scholar to write about practical and theoretical mathematics
became familiar with the Roman numeral system during his travels
questions.correctAnswer: learned of the Hindu-Arabic numeral system in North Africa

questions.passage: Text II - Fibonacci and the Hindu-Arabic number system
questions.question: It can be inferred from the second paragraph that the Liber abaci -
options: is based on what Fibonacci learned in his travels
demonstrates how to combine the Hindu-Arabic number system with the Roman number system
is devoted entirely to practical arithmetic
presents the advantages and disadvantages of the Hindu-Arabic number system
questions.correctAnswer: is based on what Fibonacci learned in his travels

questions.passage: Text II - Fibonacci and the Hindu-Arabic number system
questions.question: According to the last paragraph, the Liber quadratorum -
options: covers fewer subjects than the Liber abaci
took a long time to write
questions.correctAnswer: covers fewer subjects than the Liber abaci

questions.passage: Text II - Fibonacci and the Hindu-Arabic number system
questions.question: The last paragraph does not mention -
options: Frederick II's response to the Liber quadratorum
questions.correctAnswer: Frederick II's response to the Liber quadratorum

questions.question: The walrus uses its whiskers to ____ shellfish hidden on the ocean floor.
With the capacity to generate 2.4 million kilowatts, the Niagara Power Project is the largest ____ of electricity to New York State.
According to world aviation officials, 2017 was ____ to date for commercial air travel.
DNA evidence has been used to clear people ____ convicted of crimes.
In October 2000, the Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation set up a scholarship fund at Cambridge University to ____ the tuition of international graduate students.
Although alpaca farmers trim their animals' wool regularly, they only ____ them completely once every two years.
Muslims are required to make a ____ to the holy city of Mecca at least once in their lifetime, if they have the means to do so.
In response to the Soviet Union's increasingly ____ stance towards dissidents, physicist Andrei Sakharov became active in the human rights movement.
Ladybugs prey on pests and hence are beneficial to gardens.
options: Like other pests, ladybugs damage the plants in a garden.
Ladybugs, which eat harmful insects, are helpful in gardens.
Ladybugs feed on garden plants and on other insects.
The presence of ladybugs in a garden keeps pests away.
questions.correctAnswer: Ladybugs, which eat harmful insects, are helpful in gardens.

questions.question: Composer and conductor Leonard Bernstein was tireless in his efforts to bring classical music to a wider audience.
options: Bernstein's many admirers never tired of his classical compositions.
Bernstein's classical music appealed to many different types of audiences.
Bernstein adapted classical compositions with the aim of making them more popular.
Bernstein dedicated himself to making classical music accessible to more people.
questions.correctAnswer: Bernstein dedicated himself to making classical music accessible to more people.

questions.question: The 16th-century political philosopher Machiavelli was adamant that political morality is not bound by ethical norms.
options: Machiavelli argued that, by their very nature, politicians are bound to behave unethically.
According to Machiavelli, politicians have a moral obligation to serve as examples of ethical behavior.
Machiavelli insisted that the ethical norms governing life do not apply to politics.
Although politics has few ethical norms, there are certain moral boundaries that politicians must not cross, according to Machiavelli.
questions.correctAnswer: Machiavelli insisted that the ethical norms governing life do not apply to politics.

questions.question: Italian tenor Enrico Caruso made his American debut in a production of Verdi's Rigoletto at the Metropolitan Opera.
options: Enrico Caruso's first performance in the United States was at the Metropolitan Opera in Verdi's Rigoletto.
Enrico Caruso's first starring role was in the Metropolitan Opera's production of Verdi's Rigoletto.
Verdi's Rigoletto debuted in the United States at the Metropolitan Opera and featured Enrico Caruso.
Enrico Caruso appeared in Verdi's Rigoletto at the opening of the Metropolitan Opera.
questions.correctAnswer: Enrico Caruso's first performance in the United States was at the Metropolitan Opera in Verdi's Rigoletto.

questions.passage: Text I - Jules Verne's Paris in the 20th Century
questions.question: The main purpose of the first paragraph is to -
options: compare Paris in the 20th Century to other novels by Jules Verne
explain why Paris in the 20th Century was not published until 1989
argue that Paris in the 20th Century is Jules Verne's greatest work
discuss the publication and content of Paris in the 20th Century
questions.correctAnswer: discuss the publication and content of Paris in the 20th Century

questions.passage: Text I - Jules Verne's Paris in the 20th Century
questions.question: According to the first paragraph, in Paris in the 20th Century Jules Verne -
options: described life in Paris as he experienced it toward the end of his lifetime
tried to show readers the importance of 20th-century technological advances
introduced subjects that had not been discussed in his other novels
accurately predicted what life would be like in the 20th century
questions.correctAnswer: accurately predicted what life would be like in the 20th century

questions.passage: Text I - Jules Verne's Paris in the 20th Century
questions.question: The main idea of the second paragraph is that Paris in the 20th Century -
options: tells the story of a young man's struggle to find happiness
should have been published many years ago
was not understood at the time it was published
presents a grim view of technological progress
questions.correctAnswer: presents a grim view of technological progress

questions.passage: Text I - Jules Verne's Paris in the 20th Century
questions.question: The main purpose of the last paragraph is to -
options: explain why Verne thought that science could be dangerous
correct a common misconception about Verne
compare Verne's work as a writer to his work as a scientist
emphasize the wealth of detail in Verne's fiction
questions.correctAnswer: correct a common misconception about Verne

questions.passage: Text I - Jules Verne's Paris in the 20th Century
questions.question: In line 21, "he had no . . . virtuous" means that Verne -
options: did not believe that science was necessarily good
tried to depict technology as negatively as possible
did not fully understand all the technical details he included in his books
did not believe that his vision of the future would prove to be accurate
questions.correctAnswer: did not believe that science was necessarily good

questions.passage: Text II - The Great Wildebeest Migration
questions.question: The main purpose of the text is to discuss the -
options: struggle for survival in east Africa

questions.passage: Text II - The Great Wildebeest Migration
questions.question: Which of the following statements about the Great Wildebeest Migration is not made in the first paragraph?
options: It passes through more than one country.
It has been taking place since ancient times.
questions.correctAnswer: It has been taking place since ancient times.

questions.passage: Text II - The Great Wildebeest Migration
questions.question: In line 8, "lends itself to" is closest in meaning to -
options: must be stopped in order to

questions.passage: Text II - The Great Wildebeest Migration
questions.question: According to the last paragraph, the wildebeest migration -
options: has attracted a great deal of attention in recent years
contributes to the balance of nature in east Africa
has never been observed from beginning to end
questions.correctAnswer: contributes to the balance of nature in east Africa

questions.passage: Text II - The Great Wildebeest Migration
questions.question: Which of the following statements about wildebeest is not made in the text?
options: They need to keep up with the herd from a very young age.
They migrate in search of water and food.
They change their route to avoid predators.
questions.correctAnswer: They change their route to avoid predators.

questions.question: The Amish people are ____: they believe that war is immoral.
Many manufacturing companies offer small promotional gifts in order to ____ sales of their products.
In 1929, English explorer Vivian Ernest Fuchs participated in a geological ____ to eastern Greenland.
Cigarette smoke ____ a toxic residue on furniture and clothing that is referred to as third-hand smoke.
The famed Sydney Opera House has a distinct shape that makes it ____.
In order for ____ results to be obtained, scientific experiments must be conducted under strictly controlled conditions.
The 200-mile-long River Thames is ____ with hundreds of small islands.
The most ____ feature of the Erechtheum temple in Athens is its southern portion, which showcases six sculpted female figures.
Borneo's orangutan population is in sharp decline.
options: Borneo's orangutans have all but disappeared.
Most of the world's remaining orangutans are found in Borneo.
In Borneo, the orangutans' habitat is becoming smaller.
The number of orangutans in Borneo is dropping dramatically.
questions.correctAnswer: The number of orangutans in Borneo is dropping dramatically.

questions.question: Biologists have studied the mating rituals of only a small percentage of the roughly 12,000 known species of butterflies.
options: The mating rituals of nearly 12,000 different species of butterflies have been studied by biologists.
More than 12,000 studies on butterflies have been conducted by biologists; only a small percentage explore mating rituals.
Approximately 12,000 species of butterflies have been identified, but biologists have studied the mating rituals of relatively few of them.
According to biologists, there are only small variations in the mating rituals of the 12,000 known species of butterflies.
questions.correctAnswer: Approximately 12,000 species of butterflies have been identified, but biologists have studied the mating rituals of relatively few of them.

questions.question: Reading John Lukacs is always rewarding.
options: All of John Lukacs's books are exciting to read.
The writings of John Lukacs are never difficult to understand.
Anything written by John Lukacs is worth reading.
Everything about John Lukacs's works is brilliant.
questions.correctAnswer: Anything written by John Lukacs is worth reading.

questions.question: Following years of stagnation, the city of Duluth, Minnesota, is poised for a period of prosperity.
options: The prosperity currently enjoyed by Duluth is expected to continue.
As Duluth expands, it is becoming an increasingly attractive urban center.
Duluth's recent change of leadership promises to stimulate development.
Duluth's financial future is looking bright after a long economic standstill.
questions.correctAnswer: Duluth's financial future is looking bright after a long economic standstill.

questions.passage: Text I - Capsule endoscopy
questions.question: It can be inferred from the first paragraph that endoscopy is ____ than the use of X-ray or ultrasound in diagnosing gastrointestinal disorders.

questions.passage: Text I - Capsule endoscopy
questions.question: In line 6, "its" refers to the -

questions.passage: Text I - Capsule endoscopy
questions.question: The second paragraph mentions nanotechnology because it -
options: is the fastest means of diagnosing gastrointestinal disorders
has become a standard medical procedure
combines a number of scientific approaches
made possible the development of capsule endoscopy
questions.correctAnswer: made possible the development of capsule endoscopy

questions.passage: Text I - Capsule endoscopy
questions.question: In line 23, "affected" is closest in meaning to -

questions.passage: Text I - Capsule endoscopy
questions.question: An appropriate title for this text would be -
options: A Medical Miracle: Curing Gastrointestinal Diseases

questions.passage: Text II - The Benin Bronzes
questions.question: The main purpose of the first paragraph is to -
options: present the background to Britain's conquest of the Kingdom of Benin
introduce museum artifacts that were plundered from Benin
provide an overview of Benin's artistic tradition
explain how the Benin Bronzes got their name
questions.correctAnswer: introduce museum artifacts that were plundered from Benin

questions.passage: Text II - The Benin Bronzes
questions.question: The main purpose of the second paragraph is to -
options: present voices calling for the return of the Benin Bronzes
describe the work of the Legacy Restoration Trust
explain why the Benin Bronzes are a painful reminder of colonialism
questions.correctAnswer: present voices calling for the return of the Benin Bronzes

questions.passage: Text II - The Benin Bronzes
questions.question: "Nevertheless" (line 21) could best be restated as -
options: Despite securing the restoration of the Benin Bronzes
Even though German museums hold a large number of Benin Bronzes
Although many institutions will not discuss the Benin Bronzes in their collections
Although some museums have said they are willing to give up the Benin Bronzes
questions.correctAnswer: Although some museums have said they are willing to give up the Benin Bronzes

questions.passage: Text II - The Benin Bronzes
questions.question: The main purpose of the last paragraph is to -
options: discuss the British Museum's position on returning the Benin Bronzes that it holds
present the British Museum's acknowledgement that the Benin Bronzes were wrongfully taken
explain how so many Benin Bronzes ended up in the British Museum
describe the British Museum's collection of Benin Bronzes
questions.correctAnswer: discuss the British Museum's position on returning the Benin Bronzes that it holds

questions.passage: Text II - The Benin Bronzes
questions.question: It can be inferred from the text that one reason many museums refuse to discuss returning the Bronzes is because the objects -
____ evidence to the contrary, many people believe that men are better drivers than women.
Anthony Blunt was stripped of his knighthood by Queen Elizabeth when ____ he had spied for the Soviet Union.
Huge profits from the sale of avocadoes in New Zealand have ____ a wave of thefts from avocado orchards.
Crows are known to hold a ____, remembering and showing aggression toward crows that have hurt them in the past.
In 2000, the 170-meter tall Washington Monument underwent extensive ____ to repair broken marble blocks, remove stains, and replace windows.
Martin Luther King Jr.'s "I Have a Dream" speech is considered one of the most important ____ in U.S. history.
____ regulations prohibit the construction of office buildings in residential neighborhoods.
As a result of drought, land clearing, and wildfires, Australia's koala population has ____ by 30 percent since 2018.
The story of Don Quixote implies that fiction and historical truth are frequently indistinguishable.
options: Don Quixote suggests that it is often impossible to tell the difference between fact and fiction.
Like many great works of fiction, Don Quixote is based primarily on actual historical events.
Some parts of Don Quixote are totally fictional, while others are rooted in historical fact.
There is more fiction than fact in Don Quixote.
questions.correctAnswer: Don Quixote suggests that it is often impossible to tell the difference between fact and fiction.

questions.question: The permanent shutdown of Greyhound bus service in Canada has exacerbated the accessibility problem faced by the country's rural communities.
options: Rural communities in Canada are protesting the closure of the Greyhound bus company.
Greyhound buses no longer service some of Canada's most remote locations due to poor infrastructure.
Due to reduced demand among rural customers, the Greyhound bus company has cancelled many of its Canadian routes.
Travel has become even more difficult for people living in the Canadian countryside since Greyhound bus service was discontinued there.
questions.correctAnswer: Travel has become even more difficult for people living in the Canadian countryside since Greyhound bus service was discontinued there.

questions.question: Throughout his career, astrophysicist Charles Greeley Abbot sought to demonstrate that fluctuations in the Sun's energy emissions have a quantifiable effect on Earth's weather.
options: After many years of research, Abbot concluded that the forces that cause variations in the Sun's energy levels are also responsible for changes in the weather on Earth.
Abbot never managed to conclusively determine how energy released by the Sun influences Earth's weather.
Abbot spent his career arguing that the Sun's energy emissions have a negligible effect on the weather on Earth.
Abbot never stopped trying to prove that Earth's weather is measurably affected by changes in the Sun's energy output.
questions.correctAnswer: Abbot never stopped trying to prove that Earth's weather is measurably affected by changes in the Sun's energy output.

questions.question: The works showcased at the International Exhibition of Modern Decorative and Industrial Arts, held in Paris in 1925, epitomized the Art Deco movement.
options: The 1925 International Exhibition of Modern Decorative and Industrial Arts in Paris was organized in order to promote Art Deco artists.
The International Exhibition of Modern Decorative and Industrial Arts, held in Paris in 1925, featured exceptional Art Deco works.
The pieces which attracted the most attention at the International Exhibition of Modern Decorative and Industrial Arts, held in Paris in 1925, were those created in the Art Deco style.
The exhibits at the 1925 International Exhibition of Modern Decorative and Industrial Arts in Paris captured the essence of the Art Deco style.
questions.correctAnswer: The exhibits at the 1925 International Exhibition of Modern Decorative and Industrial Arts in Paris captured the essence of the Art Deco style.

questions.passage: Text I - Queen Anne's lace (wildflower)
questions.question: An appropriate title for this text would be -

questions.passage: Text I - Queen Anne's lace (wildflower)
questions.question: According to the first paragraph Queen Anne's lace -
options: is found in very few places
is from the same family as the carrot
questions.correctAnswer: is from the same family as the carrot

questions.passage: Text I - Queen Anne's lace (wildflower)
questions.question: The second paragraph is mainly about -
options: how to make Queen Anne's lace
what Queen Anne's lace looks like
questions.correctAnswer: what Queen Anne's lace looks like

questions.passage: Text II - Nostradamus and prophecy
questions.question: An appropriate title for this text would be -
options: The Prophecies: A Window into the Future
The Life and Works of Nostradamus

questions.passage: Text II - Nostradamus and prophecy
questions.question: In line 4, "veritable" is closest in meaning to -

questions.passage: Text II - Nostradamus and prophecy
questions.question: Which of the following is not mentioned in the second paragraph as a characteristic of Nostradamus's quatrains?
options: They are not arranged in chronological order.

questions.passage: Text II - Nostradamus and prophecy
questions.question: According to the last paragraph, Nostradamus -
options: predicted things that were sure to occur
was not a particularly good writer
questions.correctAnswer: predicted things that were sure to occur

questions.passage: Text II - Nostradamus and prophecy
questions.question: It can be inferred that the sources mentioned in line 16 -
options: cannot explain why Nostradamus was able to predict certain events
have devoted themselves to interpreting Nostradamus's work
do not think Nostradamus wrote The Prophecies

questions.question: Because dogs have upturned tails and wolves do not, biologist Carl Linnaeus ____ as different species in 1758.
The ____ surrounding the death of Che Guevara, the Cuban revolutionary leader, are unknown.
Egyptian pharaoh Tutankhamun is often referred to as the Boy King because his ____ began when he was only nine years old.
There is a wide range of ____ for which a hockey player may be sent off the ice.
In the summer of 2003, Europe suffered a severe heat wave, with temperatures in southern Portugal reaching a ____ 48 degrees Celsius.
Tensions in Central Asia are ____ as several countries compete for access to a dwindling supply of fresh water.
In northeastern India, fires ignited in a coal mine almost a century ago are still ____ deep below the earth's surface.
Evergreens are ____ trees, able to thrive in the most inhospitable conditions.
A man cannot be comfortable without his own approval. (Mark Twain)
options: Self-respect comes from having respect for others.
Well-being is possible only for those who accept themselves.
It is difficult to respect people who do not respect themselves.
Knowing oneself is the first step towards liking oneself.
questions.correctAnswer: Well-being is possible only for those who accept themselves.

questions.question: Physicist Murray Gell-Mann conducted groundbreaking research in the 1960s on a class of elementary particles that came to be known as quarks.
options: A group of elementary particles, later called quarks, was the subject of pioneering work done by Murray Gell-Mann.
In 1960, Murray Gell-Mann named the elementary particles he discovered quarks.
Murray Gell-Mann began his innovative study on quarks and other elementary particles in the 1960s.
A noteworthy study by Murray Gell-Mann on elementary particles known as quarks established him as the leading physicist of his day.
questions.correctAnswer: A group of elementary particles, later called quarks, was the subject of pioneering work done by Murray Gell-Mann.

questions.question: Livy was unique among Roman historians in that he played no part in politics.
options: Livy's political views were not reflected in his historical writings.
Livy was one of the few Roman historians with no political background.
Livy was the only Roman historian who was not involved in politics.
Livy's historical writings do not relate to Roman politics.
questions.correctAnswer: Livy was the only Roman historian who was not involved in politics.

questions.question: In June 1977, the Royal Geographical Society embarked on a 15-month inventory of the flora and fauna in Borneo's Gunung Mulu National Park.
options: In June 1977, the Royal Geographical Society recommended that the flora and fauna found in Gunung Mulu National Park be given protected status for 15 months.
The Royal Geographical Society's study of the flora and fauna in Borneo's Gunung Mulu National Park took 15 months longer than expected.
Borneo's Gunung Mulu National Park was reopened in June 1977 after the Royal Geographical Society spent 15 months restoring the park's flora and fauna.
A list of the flora and fauna in Gunung Mulu National Park was prepared by the Royal Geographical Society over a period of 15 months, beginning in June 1977.
questions.correctAnswer: A list of the flora and fauna in Gunung Mulu National Park was prepared by the Royal Geographical Society over a period of 15 months, beginning in June 1977.

questions.passage: Text I - Composting
questions.question: An appropriate title for this text would be -
options: The Advantages and Disadvantages of Composting
Composting: An Easy Way to Help the Environment
Buried Waste: The Dangers of Landfills
questions.correctAnswer: Composting: An Easy Way to Help the Environment

questions.passage: Text I - Composting
questions.question: Which of the following is not mentioned in the first paragraph as a problem related to dumps and landfills?
options: They pollute the air, water, and soil.

questions.passage: Text I - Composting
questions.question: According to the second paragraph, which of the following is not needed to make compost?

questions.passage: Text I - Composting
questions.question: The main purpose of the last paragraph is to discuss ____ of composting.

questions.passage: Text I - Composting
questions.question: According to the text, what is the difference between decomposing and rotting?
options: Decomposing breaks waste down into nutrients, while rotting produces dangerous pollutants.
Only biodegradable waste decomposes, but any type of household garbage will rot.
Waste decomposes when it is buried but rots when exposed to air.
Decomposing is a much longer process than rotting.
questions.correctAnswer: Decomposing breaks waste down into nutrients, while rotting produces dangerous pollutants.

questions.passage: Text II - Walking and creativity
questions.question: The main purpose of the first paragraph is to -
options: explain how walking can help solve problems
present the idea that walking improves one's thinking
present ways in which walking contributes to one's health
questions.correctAnswer: present the idea that walking improves one's thinking

questions.passage: Text II - Walking and creativity
questions.question: According to the second paragraph, Beethoven, Wordsworth, and Thoreau -
options: went walking when they needed to solve a problem
enjoyed good health as a result of walking
felt that walking was helpful to them
began most of their works while walking
questions.correctAnswer: felt that walking was helpful to them

questions.passage: Text II - Walking and creativity
questions.question: It can be inferred from the second paragraph that Beethoven's Pastoral Symphony -
options: was the only one of Beethoven's works written about nature
was begun after a walk in nature
questions.correctAnswer: was begun after a walk in nature

questions.passage: Text II - Walking and creativity
questions.question: The main purpose of the last paragraph is to -
options: present research that shows that walking has an impact on one's creative process
compare the claims of Sowden, Oppezzo, and Schwartz with regard to creativity
discuss ways to improve attention, memory, and recovery from mental fatigue
discuss the results of the Stanford University experiment
questions.correctAnswer: present research that shows that walking has an impact on one's creative process

questions.passage: Text II - Walking and creativity
questions.question: Which of the following statements would Dr. Sowden be most likely to agree with?
options: Mental fatigue is the greatest challenge faced by creative people.
Creativity depends more on awareness than memory.
The creative process is most improved by sitting outside.
Claims that walking contributes to creativity are not speculative.
questions.correctAnswer: Claims that walking contributes to creativity are not speculative.
